tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.
Here "light" represents life. AT: "Yahweh is the source of my life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This question emphasizes that there is no one that David should fear. AT: "I will not be afraid of anyone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This speaks about Yahweh as if he were a place where people can go for safety. AT: "Yahweh is the one who keeps me safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This question emphasizes that there is no one that David should be afraid of. AT: "I will not dread anyone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Destroying someone completely is spoken of as if it were devouring a person's flesh. He did not mean that they wanted to eat his body. AT: "to destroy me"  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
These words mean the same thing. These are the evildoers who came near to him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
This represents the writer's enemies failing to fulfill their plans to harm the writer. AT: "did not succeed" or "failed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Though an army encamps against me
tn.text: "though an army surrounds me" or "though an army puts its tents around me"
Here "heart" represents the whole person. AT: "I will not be afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
The writer enemies are spoken of as if they themselves were a war. AT: "though my enemies come to fight me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"I will continue to trust God to help me"
"I have asked Yahweh to let me do"
A person really wanting something and continually asking God for it is spoken of as if he were seeking to find something. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: to see the beauty of Yahweh
tn.text: The wonderful character of God is spoken of as if it were physical beauty. AT: "to see how wonderful Yahweh is" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Possible meanings are 1) "to ask God what he wants me to do" or 2) "to think carefully about God in his temple."
Here "day" represents a longer period of time. AT: "in the time of trouble" or "when I have troubles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"he will protect me"
Both of these refer to the tabernacle where the writer is worshiping God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: in the cover of his tent
tn.text: The word "cover" represents something that hides and protects.

tn.ref: He will lift me high on a rock
tn.text: God keeping the writer safe from his enemies is spoken of as if God were placing him on a high rock where his enemies cannot reach him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: my head will be lifted up above my enemies
tn.text: This represents the writer receiving pride or honor when he defeats his enemies. It can be stated in active form. AT: "people will honor me when I win the fight against my enemies" or "God will honor me by enabling me to defeat my enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "voice" represents what the writers is saying. AT: "Hear me, Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This implies that Yahweh hears the writer's prayer and Yahweh will do what the writer asks. AT: "answer my prayer" (UDB) or "do what I request of you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "heart" represents a person's mind or thoughts. AT: "In my heart I say" or "I say to myself" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

A person going to the temple to pray to Yahweh is spoken of as if the person were seeking to find Yahweh. Here "face" represents all of God. AT: "Go and pray to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

A person going to the temple to pray to Yahweh is spoken of as if the person were seeking to find Yahweh. Here "face" represents all of God. AT: "I will come to your temple to pray to you" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Do not hide your face from me
tn.text: The face here represents Yahweh's attention. The phrase "do not hide your face" is a way of asking God not to reject him. AT: "Do not reject me" or "Do not stop taking care of me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: do not turn your servant away in anger
tn.text: David said "your servant" to refer to himself in a humble way. AT: "do not be angry with me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_123person]])
The words "forsake" and "abandon" mean the same thing. The writer is emphasizing that he does not want God to leave him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
The words "and do not" are understood. AT: "and do not abandon me" or "and do not leave me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated as "saves." AT: God who saves me" or because you are the God who saves me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: Even if my father and my mother forsake me
tn.text: "Even if my father and my mother were to forsake me." He is not saying that they actually have done this or that they would do it. His point is that even if they did that, God would not abandon him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
"Yahweh will keep me" or "Yahweh will take care of me"

How a person should behave is spoken of as if it were a way or path that person should travel. AT: "Teach me how you want me to live" or "Teach me to do what you want me to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Lead me on a level path
tn.text: Yahweh keeping the writer safe from his enemies is spoken of as if Yahweh leads the writer on a level path where he will not stumble and fall. AT: "Keep me safe" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Do not give me up to the desires of my enemies
tn.text: The abstract noun "desires" can be stated as a verb. AT: "Do not let my enemies do to me what they desire" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"Risen up" is an idiom meaning that a witness stood in court to present testimony. AT: "have stood up in order to speak against me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here violence is spoken for as if it was something a person could breathe out. AT: "they say that they will do violent things to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: What would have happened to me
tn.text: This rhetorical question can be stated positively. AT: "Something bad would have happened to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The abstract noun "goodness" can be stated as an adjective. AT: "the good things that Yahweh does" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: in the land of the living
tn.text: This refers to being alive. AT: "while I am alive" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Wait for Yahweh ... Wait for Yahweh!
tn.text: This verse may be 1) the writer speaking to himself or 2) the writer speaking to others or 3) someone speaking to the writer.
Here "heart" represents the whole person. AT: "be courageous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This line is repeated at the end of the psalm as a way of ending the psalm.
